filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of a digital edition of forty-three pencil drawings produced by Blake during his first decade as an independent artist, 1779-1790. Drawing lies at the core of Blake's life as an artist. Pencil was his preferred medium for sketching—more flexible, less expensive, and more easily corrected than pen and ink or chalk. Preliminary work with the pencil preceded more finished work, either as separate sketches for prints and paintings or as drawings underlying water colors. Blake's nineteenth-century writings on the arts testify to his conviction that drawing was fundamental to all pictorial expression: "The distinction that is made in modern times between a Painting and a Drawing proceeds from ignorance of art. The merit of a Picture is the same as the merit of a Drawing" (*A Descriptive Catalogue*, Erdman page 549); "Let a Man who has made a Drawing go on & on & he will produce a Picture or Painting but if he chooses to leave off before he has spoild it he will Do a Better Thing[.]" (*Public Address*, Erdman page 576); "Painting is Drawing on Canvas & Engraving is Drawing on Copper & Nothing Else…& he who Draws best must be the best Artist…." (*Public Address*, Erdman page 582); "Dear Sir, excuse my enthusiasm or rather madness, for I am really drunk with intellectual vision whenever I take a pencil or graver into my hand…." (letter to William Hayley, 1804, Erdman page 757).
Blake no doubt executed a great many more pencil drawings than those extant today. Sketches were not intended for exhibition or sale; most were probably discarded, while others may have been retained only because of more developed compositions on the other side of the leaves. Even the slightest and least aesthetically ambitious drawings offer insights into the origins and earliest realizations of Blake’s designs. These first thoughts on paper often tell us more about Blake’s habits of mind, when joined by eye and hand, than more finished works. Sketches are “the first fruits of [Blake’s] imagination,” as Geoffrey Keynes states in the introduction to his *Pencil Drawings of William Blake* (1927).
The forty-three pencil drawings presented here, produced in Blake’s first decade as an independent artist, show his early debt to academic standards of precise copying and to the neoclassical emphasis on outline. The first four works may have been drawn while Blake was a student in the Royal Academy schools. Other sketches are preliminaries for some of Blake’s most important designs. Among these are the *Study for “Glad Day”, or “Albion Rose”* ( Object 6), Blake’s iconic vision of the human form divine in energetic pose, and three sketches (Objects 34-36) for illustrations to *Tiriel*, the only group of finished drawings Blake composed for one of his own poems. Several sketches are early efforts at picturing events in the Bible, Blake’s main inspiration for designs throughout his life. This biblical cluster includes *The Resurrection of the Dead* (Object 10), *Samuel Presenting Saul to the People* (Object 15), and *Job’s Wife and Other Sketches* (Object 31). Other studies, such as *Ugolino in Prison* and its verso (Objects 21-22), reveal the beginnings of subjects also of lifelong interest for Blake. Only a few drawings for Blake’s illuminated books have survived, but studies such as *Sketches for “The Book of Thel”* and *A Standing and a Recumbent Figure* (Objects 37-39) offer fascinating glimpses into Blake’s methods of graphic production and revision.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

provenance.note: Inherited by Blake's wife Catherine at his death in 1827; acquired by Frederick Tatham, probably at Catherine Blake's death in 1831; the dealer Bernard Quaritch, offered in his Nov. 1882 catalogue, item 346 with 39 other works (£36), catalogue 350 of 10 Aug. 1883, item 13843, same group and price, *Catalogue of Works on the Fine Arts* of Oct. 1883, item 13843, same group and price, and catalogue of *William Blake's Original Drawings* of May 1885, no item number, same group and price; sold by Quaritch on 30 June 1886 to W. Graham Robertson; sold from Robertson's collection, Christie's, 22 July 1949, lot 73 with two other works by Blake and one by his brother Robert (£18.18s. to the dealer Maggs Bros. Ltd.); George Goyder, sold by him or placed on consignment with Thomas Agnew & Sons; sold 1966 to Gwen Mond, Lady Melchett; sold from her collection, Christie's, 9 Nov. 1971, lot 79, titled "The Deluge" (£170.8s.6d. to R. D. McDonald); sold Christie's, 17 Nov. 1992, lot 16 (£7150 to Salander-O'Reilly Galleries, New York); sold Sotheby's, 4 Dec. 2008, lot 120 (£3500 to the dealer John Windle); offered by Windle in his catalogue 46 of Oct. 2009, item 2 ($47,500); acquired Jan. 2011 from Windle by Robert N. Essick ($15,000).

desc.objtitle: *The Resurrection of the Dead*, object 1 (Butlin 79 recto)

objnote.p: The verso of this leaf bears pencil sketches for Blake's 1802 *Designs to a Series of Ballads, Written by William Hayley* (the verso sketches not in Butlin because not discovered until 2009). This recto sketch is probably a variant preliminary drawing for a wash drawing, *The Resurrection of the Dead or The Last Trumpet* (Butlin 617, listed as untraced since 1922) in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, accession number 2011.448.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This drawing shows the resurrection of the dead (Revelation 20). A trumpeting figure flies or hovers in the upper half of the drawing above several figures, all visible from approximately the waist up, some of whom raise their arms upward in this resurrection scene. These figures may emerge from the ground or a body of water (see "the sea gave up the dead," Revelation 20:13). The above figure appears to fly in from the right and face forward. It may wear a gown; both arms are raised horizontally and extended to hold the end of a trumpet into which the figure blows. Lines emerging from the musical instrument may indicate sound or, alternatively, suggest surrounding clouds. In the lower right quadrant, a group of at least five figures huddle together. The leftmost of these appears to be a woman (perhaps with long hair arranged in a bun?) who faces right with eyes raised. She holds a short-haired infant or child who raises its bent right arm at approximately 135 degrees. Directly to the right of the female figure's head, an adult male's head is visible also facing right and up. He has short hair and may reach his right arm around the female at left, resting his hand on her right shoulder. A fourth, smaller figure (perhaps a child or adolescent?) is visible directly below the male's head; this figure faces right, perhaps with eyes closed, and raises its left arm at 135 degrees. The rightmost figure in this group is the least clear but a head and shoulders appear to be visible behind and to the right of the adult male. To the left of this group in the bottom center of the drawing, a pair of nude male figures, one in front of the other, raise their arms vertically with fingers spread. Like the figures to their right, they face right and up. The mouth of the figure closer to the viewer is open, and he appears to have a beard. There may be a third group of figures in the lower left quadrant but the details of these figures are indistinct.

component.illusobjdesc: A trumpeting figure flies or hovers in the upper half of the drawing. With body horizontal, the figure appears to fly in from the right and face forward, perhaps with eyes turned down to look at the figures below. He(?) may wear a gown. Both arms are raised horizontally and extended to hold the end of a trumpet into which the figure blows.
The flying figure in the upper half of the drawing holds a trumpet that he appears to play.

The swirling lines that emerge from the bell of the trumpet played by the flying figure in the upper half of the composition may indicate sound or, alternatively, suggest surrounding clouds. Curved lines below the figure in the upper right quadrant may also represent clouds.

In the lower right quadrant, a group of at least five figures, who may represent a family, huddle together. The heads, shoulders, and arms of these figures are the only body parts visible as they may emerge from the ground or the "sea" (see Revelation 20.:13) in this resurrection scene.

The leftmost figure in the group lower right appears to be a woman (perhaps with long hair arranged in a bun?) who faces right with eyes raised. She may be the mother if the group is a family as her bent right arm supports an infant or child.
The leftmost female figure holds a short-haired infant or child who faces right and up and raises its bent right arm at approximately 135 degrees.

Directly to the right of the female figure's head, an adult male's head is visible also facing right and up with eyes raised. He has short hair and may reach his right arm around the female at left, resting his hand on her right shoulder in an embrace. He may be the father if this group is a family.

A fourth, smaller figure (perhaps a child or adolescent?) is visible directly below the male's head; this figure faces right, perhaps with eyes closed, and raises its bent left arm at 135 degrees. Some (but not all) of the figure's fingers are extended, perhaps in a gesture of pointing.

The rightmost figure in the group at lower right is the least clear, but a head and shoulders appear to be visible behind and to the right of the adult male. This figure may wear a hat or have short hair(?).

In the bottom center of the drawing, a pair of nude male figures, one in front of the other, raise their bent arms vertically with fingers spread. Like the figures to their right, they face right and up with eyes raised and appear to emerge from the ground or the "sea" (see Revelation 20:13). The mouth of the figure closer to the viewer is open, and he appears to have a beard. He may lean slightly to the right.

In the bottom center of the drawing, a pair of nude male figures, one in front of the other, raise their bent arms vertically with fingers spread. Like the figures to their right, they face right and up with eyes raised and appear to emerge from the ground or the "sea" (see Revelation 20:13). The figure further from the viewer may be bearded; he leans to the right.
A cluster of lines lower left may be two or more figures emerging from the earth or the "sea" (see Revelation 20:13). Perhaps their heads and upper bodies are visible, but the details are unclear.
